findings.description: The setMinter function allows any authorized minter to add new minters without any restrictions or multi-signature requirement. This violates the intended multi-signer minting system established in the constructor, where MIN_SIGNERS (2) minters were required initially.
findings.reasoning: The finding correctly identifies a real access control vulnerability in the setMinter function (lines 65-67). The issue is that any single authorized minter can unilaterally add new minters, bypassing the multi-signature requirement implied by MIN_SIGNERS. This is a valid, exploitable vulnerability that is NOT the target vulnerability. The target vulnerability is in the mint function (line 49), which allows any authorized minter to mint tokens without requiring approval from other minters. The finding is BONUS_VALID because it identifies a different but real and critical access control issue.

target_assessment.type_match_reasoning: The finding discusses setMinter function, but the target vulnerability is in the mint function. The finding does not mention the mint function at all, so there is no type match.

notes: The audit finding correctly identifies a critical access control vulnerability in the setMinter function, but it is NOT the target vulnerability specified in the ground truth. The target vulnerability is in the mint function (any single minter can mint tokens without multi-signature approval), while the finding identifies a vulnerability in setMinter (any single minter can add new minters). Both are valid critical access control issues, but they are distinct vulnerabilities in different functions.
